Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned absolutely nothing from this course. This is most definitely the worst laboratory course I have taken so far at Yale.
I learned some basic skills such as how to use logger pro and how to do various physical experiments.
the syllabus promises the topics and delivers
I learned a lot about physics, and developed a greater intuition and sense of how these concepts affect the real world.

This course develops a different set of knowledge and skills that other (e.g. chemistry or biology) lab courses do. This course isn't about bogging you down with incredibly long lab reports, confusing course packets or intricate scientific methods. Instead, it teaches you to be more of an independent researcher. The course packet doesn't really give detailed step-by-step instructions, and a lot of times the student can choose how to proceed in the lab. I imagine that many students find this frustrating, but as someone who has been working in a lab on an independent project this semester, I really appreciate that this course tried to develop our independence as scientists.
This lab teaches students about fundamental experimental techniques that can be used to test many of the topics discussed in physics lecture.
I learned general physics lab concepts and how to operate LoggerPro.

I definitely developed skills using LoggerPro software, which was pretty much used in every single lab. I have never used this software before, so I was a little shaky at the start but you definitely get used to it throughout the semester.
This course reinforced how physics laws worked, and taught me how to assess an experimental set-up for sources of error.
I learned how to use LoggerPro and understand theoretical physics concepts through experimentation.

You work through various physics labs to re-assert/engrain multiple laws of physics through experimentation. The most important thing I learned in lab was probably how to properly calculate uncertainties in measurements (which was always very important). You also learn how to keep a neat lab notebooks so that you can easily write a lab report.
Basic physics lab techniques (measuring velocity, weighing, timing, etc.), Logger Pro skills, putting some physics concepts into more tangible examples
Absolutely nothing, besides how to click points on a computer screen.
phys lab
I learned how to use theoretical physics principles to understand and analyze real-world data.
I learned how to prove basic physics laws which was really interesting. I also learned a lot about uncertainty and how to account for it and calculate it.
I learned about the physical manifestations of much of the physics I have learned in the last few years.
How to try to fake your way into getting insight points on lab reports.
How physics experiments are designed, how to collect data with LoggerPro, how to calculate and propagate error
Practical experience applying basic physics concepts learned in class
You learn how the equations in physics are applied to physical objects.
A bit of critical thinking, and some applications of physics. Not a bad course to take as a lab requirement though.
How to succinctly summarize experimental findings
I learned to use experimental designs to apply physics knowledge.
I didn't learn much taking this course. I had already taken physics classes that covered far more than this course. I took it because I thought I needed it for my major but then I switched majors.
Learned basic mechanics, like gravity, linear motion, rotational motion, resistance, pendulums, etc.
Almost nothing. Maybe some error, but I probably won't use it
LoggerPro use and Vernier. Calculation of uncertainty. Better conceptual understanding of many physics concepts.
I learned basic physics laboratory skills.

A standard physics lab consisting of complementary experiments to the laboratory courses. I learned physical and practical techniques to assist in my understanding of physics topics learned in lecture.
How to use experimental apparatus such as a motion detector and analyze data using LoggerPro.
I learned how to calculate uncertainties.

I learned some physics concepts and how to investigate them in a laboratory setting. I also got to practice thinking about how to extend a lab if there were more time and resources for further investigation.
Most of what I took away from this course was how to take more accurate measurements in the lab and analyze the extent of errors in the data.

I definitely improved my attention to detail and ability to do error propagation. I felt like I got better at writing the 1 page lab reports as time went on, and as much as the weekly lab reports felt like a slog, I felt like I learned a lot about basic physics experiments.
I learned how to use basic equipment used in physics labs as well as how to use experimental results to draw conclusions about physics concepts.
Physics 165L is definitely a requirement. I found it cool to get some hands on experience with physics, but some parts tied in with the course better than others.
I learned a lot about uncertainty calculations, pendulums, and angular momentum. I also learned how to use loggerpro.
I learned how to take a analyze physical measurements.
How to apply the things we learn in physics lecture to real life.
Physical applications of the theoretical material covered in PHYS 180. Overall, interesting labs that illustrate concepts well.

The experiments conducted in this lab were not always related to course material directly, but when they were, they definitely contributed to my understanding of course concepts (and helped me discern what actually makes physical sense/what doesn't). The course also helps a lot in understanding error propagation and sources and varieties that arise during lab work.
lots of cool physics concept and machines
How to use LoggerPro, basic physics lab concepts
The only things I really learned were how to creat calculated columns in Logger Pro and how to calculate uncertainty.
Some basic physics principles
I learned how to do uncertainties.

You learn a lot about physics in the lab that reinforced what you learned in the classroom. At times I felt like I didn't have the background physics knowledge to know what the lab was trying to teach but later in the semester learned about the topic. In reality this class helped with Physics 180 more than physics 180 helped with this class.
I learned how to apply and test physics concepts.
Able to carry out a physics lab
The class largely felt like an introduction to lab science, so I would say I gained an elementary understanding of lab courses at Yale.

Honestly, the only skills I took away from this course were how to use LoggerPro and how to relate plotted data to different functions. I do not feel that my understanding of physics concepts improved greatly throughout the course of the semester.
I learned how to apply the physics concepts I learned in general physics lecture. This course is essentially based on using LoggerPro, so I became a pro at that too.
A knowledge of the physical world was enhanced through difference tangible observations.

In this course, I learned how to analyze and think about physical concepts in a laboratory setting, and to develop insights about how said concepts could be found in everyday life as well. I enjoyed the experiments and found the teaching staff to be helpful.
I learned how to apply physics concepts to experiments, which helped me gain a better understanding of how these concepts are proven in real life.
I learned how to apply physics concepts to tangible demonstrations and actually started to be able to think about how to construct experimentation to test concepts.
From this course I learned how to apply basic physics principles in a lab setting.
I learned to demonstrate physical properties that I had learned in class.
I learned how to calculate uncertainty.

Honestly, I didn't learn much. I guess I became familiar with basic techniques of using Logger Pro, photogates, video capture. The angular momentum lab with the bicycle wheel/gyroscope was interesting but otherwise I barely learned anything. All the concepts were very basic and doing lab was simply not useful. Waste of time.
I learned about experimentally testing and proving physical theories and laws.
Basic introductory physics lab skills. Pretty self-explanatory...

The course is designed to give a general overview of basic concepts in practical physics. The labs are mostly organized with manuals that give step-by-step instruction on how to complete the experiments but there is a lot of good information in the explanations and derivations if you truly take the time to understand the material. There is heavy emphasis on understanding the imprecision of physical science and the use of uncertainty in all quantitative measurements.
Real-life applications of physics was very helpful; especially, when taken concurrently with the lecture course.

I solidified my knowledge in mechanics (although most, if not all, of the material was familiar to me through AP Physics and PHYS 180). I learned how to use LoggerPro. I learned how to do error calculations and how to propagate error.
I learned how to use LoggerPro to track motion, create graphs, and analyze data. I was able to apply the concepts I used in lecture.
learned very very little in this course

I'm sure you're taking this class because you have to. It's just so boring, mundane, tedious, etc. I firmly believe you'll learn almost nothing that you won't already know from physics class and the reason these labs continue to exist baffles me. This sounds harsh and it's not directed towards the instructors -- they're doing the best they can considering they're teaching a pointless class. The emphasis on uncertainties, though, I have to say is unbelievably stupid. Show them once or twice, a few times. Test it once on a quiz or on the midterm, etc to ensure students understand it, fine. But to waste our time, week after week, calculating uncertainties when there are uncertainty calculators, is one of the most idiotic exercises imaginable.
Basically, I got really good at taking into account and calculating uncertainties. The experiments themselves were quite simple. I guess I got better at the practices of a thorough lab notebook too.
I was able to apply my knowledge of physics to the experiments.
The lab complimented the material taught in PHYS 180 in a great way, allowing me to experience physical concepts in a more tangible way.
Learned a lot about LoggerPro!
I learned some cool basic physics
I learned how to apply and evaluate certain physical concepts in the real world.
Through this physics lab course, I was able to gain a basic understanding of lab procedure and understand how to apply the physics concepts I learned in PHYS 180 in a real life setting.

I learned about real world applications of physics concepts learned in PHYS 180. A skill I acquired is the ability to use LoggerPro to model physical motion by graphing position, velocity, or acceleration 
of an object versus time.
Learned how to test physics theories through experiments and how to account for uncertainty and about a lot of set ups...
This course helped me get an understanding of how the physics concepts I was learning apply to real life through experiments.
I learned many practical applications of physics
Learned about using LoggerPro and doing uncertainty calculations.
Enforced physics concepts from the lecture course in addition to general experimental skills.
I was able to obtain a solid foundation on many physics concepts and complement those learned in the lecture course.
I learned about Physics in the lab setting by performing various experiments.

The experiments were really quite boring and tedious, and not well connected at all with the PHYS 170 curriculum. The most useful thing I learned was how to calculate uncertainties and cope with the quirks of Loggerpro.

I learned how to develop procedures to test physical principles. I learned how to use logger pro and other graphing/spreadsheet software as well as how to calculate error correctly. I applied some of the concepts from my lecture course in this lab.
I learned how to use different tools in the lab and how to calculate significant figures.
This class is pretty useless.
I gained a great understanding of various physical principles.
I gained basic skills in laboratory procedure.
I learned the basics of working in a lab and how to use loggerpro
how to apply basic concepts to physical applications
The most useful part of this class was its thorough explanation of experimental error and how to measure it.
Learned some physics concepts, but most were already taught or would be taught in physics lecture.
I became more comfortable with using LoggerPro and the general concepts behind general physics.
I learnt basic laboratory techniques to investigate questions and theories in physics.
The course was useful in teaching physics concepts through experiments.
Practical knowledge of physics applications and deeper understanding of physics concepts.
How to write good and succinct lab reports; how to work with a partner

We learned to apply the theorems of physics that we learned in class and improved our intuition about the effects that the laws of physics would have.  We also learned many techniques to measure quantities of interest.
I learned a lot about physical applications and how the formulas could be proven in real experiments.

The course claims to be a stand-alone course but really it is an attempt to tailor physics to both physics 180 and 170 (although it does so successfully for physics 180 to be honest). 

The TAs were very supportive during labs and did help clarify any questions, though.

The midterm exam seemed quite pointless. I also think that having 10 point multiple choice questions on a 100 point exam was rather excessive. I would prefer to have more multiple choice questions, but have them each be worth something like 2-5 points.

The expectations for this course are not clear at all. There are vague instructions on Canvas, and then even if they are followed, points are deducted. Also the final examination was not a fair comparison to any of the labs we completed throughout the semester.

This course focuses way too much on uncertainties - yes they are important, and yes it is good to acknowledge them, but they should not be the central focus of this course. Other than that, this was a decent course.

strengths: well-organized, reasonable workload i.e. short lab reports, helpful TAs and professors

weaknesses: some experiments were way too involved with very little intellectual payoff (too many parts), final exam was disproportionately difficult in some portions (with too much weight on any given portion, including multiple choice)
the exams weren't fair

Strengths: well organized, well taught
Weaknessess: none

Strengths: This course is pretty low workload. Lab reports are just one page, the quizzes are short and reasonable, the lab packets and experiments aren't too long, and they are generally pretty transparent about the grading. If you're coming out of gen chem lab this will feel like a breeze.

Weaknesses: The grading is a little strange. The course average is very high; basically everyone gets a perfect or near-perfect on the lab repots and quizzes. The final is then made unnecessarily hard in order to introduce a grading curve. I think this is an awful way to assign final grades and is definitely the weakness of the course.

The course design is fine and it's clear that each week has a specific purpose. I think that the current report structure is kind of odd. It's nice that we only have to write one page but most of the time it felt a bit pointless. I understand that the instructors want students to reflect on each experiment but I'm pretty sure most students just write a couple paragraphs about sources of error that are already discussed in the course packet. Understanding error is important but I think asking students to respond to a couple of specific questions about each experiment would create more engagement with the class.
This course is good at covering the basics. However, with its focus on menial details and tedious calculations, one easily began to resent the subject.

The lab investigates the main topics of mechanics with interesting labs, but a couple of the labs were so meticulous with calculations that it seemed over the top and took away from the point of the experiment. This was often due to uncertainty calculations. If we could have spent a bit of time clarifying the rules of uncertainty, and not doing as much with it as we sometimes did, it would improve the experiments.
Strengths -- content in experiments matched lecture material. lab hand-outs provided important theoretical framework.

My strengths were my lab reports and lab notebook notes. I was organised and thorough in my explanations. 

My weaknesses involved figuring things out on the spot (normally during lab hours) i.e. how to solve for particular parameters using our values - it involved a lot of math.

Strengths -- I enjoyed that the lab reports were about synthesizing results to think about sources of error and applications of the properties being studied. They weren't tedious, and seemed to have a purpose.

Weaknesses -- The error calculations could sometimes feel tedious.

This class had a great lab report policy. I think the work was suitable for a 0.5 credit course, unlike gen chem lab. However, I felt the midterm was unfairly difficult and that the multiple choice was worth way to many points.

The lab was very comprehensive. It covered many different physics properties through very memorable experiments. All the TA's and professors for the lab were always very helpful during the lab as well
This course is sometimes tedious if you are not interested in the material.

Strengths: Post-labs are short and concise. This makes a lot of sense + is formatted well. TAs do not make you waste time/be superfluous. 

Weaknesses: The exams are a very poor way to test how well you are doing in lab. The high pressure/timed environment is in no way representative of how lab work will be in reality. Some experiments are tedious and repeat sections unnecessarily.

This course could benefit from being greatly improved. As it stands now, most labs do not supplement the material covered in PHYS 180, it simply reinforces concepts. Most labs are mundane and do not help prove anything further than an in-lecture proof wouldn't help elucidate.

Furthermore, there needs to be a greater emphasis on scientific writing if grading largely depends on it. Week after week, students kept getting points off for "insight" with the only recommendation being "add insight." The "insight" that was ultimately accepted was not an understanding of the concepts, but a very brief statement just mentioning some random application loosely related to the concept.
it's a good class, at times more confusing than it needs to be. also very ta dependent in terms of grades and explanations.
I thought the labs were interesting and thought-provoking. However, the midterm and final exams were more difficult than the labs to complete.

It feels like I am in high school all over again. This class does not overlap much with PHYS 170; I felt like I was doing a random assignment that had more to do with my knowledge of LoggerPro than actual physics each week.
Grading is way harsher than it needs to be. Lab practicals are insane. This class takes way more time than it needs to for half a credit.
Packets posted on canvas were very useful

Generally experiments' purposes and greater relevance were clear. Grading expectations (namely that reports had to include some comment connecting the experiment to real life and had to propose potential sources of error) should have been made clearer from the beginning of the class.

It's a good lab class that is pretty low-key which is a nice complement to the class. quizzes and labs were good if it could be improved maybe just try to line up the information learned in physics class with the information in lab, the lab went a little faster.

Strengths: No long lab reports (only a weekly page-long summary of the experiment), shorter than other science labs

Weaknesses: Sometimes I didn't understand the mathematical concepts behind the experiments; this became a problem on the final practical, so make sure you understand the math even if you think it's obscure! This was not emphasized enough in lab itself

Nothing in this class was explained, and there are so many assumptions made about how much and how comfortable students are with physics. its not fair that the lab is introducing new concepts before the lectures are, and then students are penalized for not understanding something totally new from a 10 page hand out. There should be more collaboration between TAs and students, way more demos, maybe some quick review before each lab begins on main concepts and tips for uncertainty. for practicals, the topics really should be released beforehand so students can prepare conceptually. also multiple choice questions should not be worth 10 points with no partial credit given. losing a letter grade on a midterm or final becuase of one question is really unfair and honestly just doesn't make sense.
The experiments can be super boring and cover material only covered by PHYS 180 vs. PHYS 170. Overall though, taught me how to do physics experiments.

I think the biggest weakness with this course is the amount of pressure put on the final due to the fact  that everyone does so well on all the labs leading up to it. I would have rather had slightly harder labs and then a easier final (or just a shorter final)
Pretty chill. Labs were easy and TAs were wonderful.
It's a pre-req and really boring

Small size, clear handouts, and great teaching fellows are the strengths. The only weakness was there was not a great introduction to Logger Pro as a handout as far as I could tell, so it was difficult for me to make sense of it at first.

This course was all right. I think it could be improved with more applications of the concepts we were learning to real life or more challenging labs -- as it is, we kind of go into a lab knowing exactly what to expect from the results, easily achieving those results, writing down what we've observed and gaining no new insights, which can be kind of tiring. That said, the general structure of the course is really well thought-out and the instructors and TAs are really great, passionate and helpful.

The course has a very low workload and only meets once a week, but it is a three hours. At times the experiments were confusing and hard to follow, but in the end I really did come out feeling like i learned something. Many peers were upset with the length and randomness of this course, but I feel it is conducted in a manner that teaches a lot about uncertainty and gaining physical techniques.

Strengths: Only 3 hours long with a one page lab summary due every week.
Weakness: The final exam was so hard.

I honestly can't think of any strengths to this course. It was that awful. The quizzes caused a great deal of anxiety, even though I read through the handouts thoroughly before each lab, the grading was ridiculously harsh, and there was never sufficient overlap between what was taught in lecture to what was being experimented with. The final was incredibly difficult, and the concepts that we needed to know to be successful on it were never fully explained during the semester. Furthermore, I found it disheartening to have been asked by one of the professors what inertia was during one lab week and was given a discourteous look for not knowing the answer. We hadn't even covered inertia in Physics 170 and yet I was expected to give a correct answer. Ridiculous. In addition, for a 0.5 credit course, this course was a lot more work than the credit allotted, and I am very disappointed in the overall structure of this course.

I feel here again that your experience in this lab really depends on the quality of your TA. Unfortunately, mine was not great and repeatedly was unable to answer questions about the labs we were performing. She also gave us incorrect information and was not open to discussing how I could improve on my lab reports. This meant my overall experience in the class was poor as the bulk of the teaching or guidance during labs was done by the TA. This is too bad because I've visited a couple of the other physics lab TA's sections and boy was it a night and day difference! They were helpful and kind and enthusiastic about teaching and the material. It's too bad I wasn't in their section, I would have learned more and also have appreciated the material more.

The final exam was absolutely absurd. This is a physics lab that many students begrudgingly take due to requirements for their major or intended profession. The lab itself was boring beyond belief, but straightforward nonetheless and imparted the necessary skills and information. The final exam, however, was trying to trip students up and used skills and material that were never covered in lab nor the corresponding introductory physics classes. Ridiculous.

The labs can be interesting, and the work is manageable. That being said, for someone who is not really interested in physics, the labs could feel long and dull at times, since they often consist of repetitive measurement and calculation. (However, I don't really think this is a reflection on the quality of the class, as this sort of measurement and calculation was important for the physics we were doing.)

I think this class is pretty well designed, the workload is easy and the labs fit well to the progression of the physics classes they are supposed to accompany. This course doesn't teach you much in the way of new physics information (especially if you take it with 180 or 200) but observing physical phenomena helps reinforce the concepts learned in lectures. I liked the added midterm this year, it really helps you feel comfortable with the practical final.

I think that the course set up was good for a intro level course and the TFs were really caring. I'm not really sure how it could be improved. For what the course is, I really liked it. The final exam was very hard though.

Strengths: great TA, very well organized

Weaknesses: quizzes were hard to study for
Some parts of the lab tied into the class better than others, but I think overall it was good!

I was taking PHYS 170 at the same time as this lab and I felt at a disadvantage. The students in PHYS 180 learned about angular momentum and torque and all of that, while those of us in 170 didn't really have that content in our lectures. The lab is supposed to complement the topics learned in the lecture course but for me it felt like a completely different class. I had to learn completely new concepts in order to understand what was happening in lab.

I thought everything about this course was pretty fair except for the final practical exam. I DID NOT think it was reflective of the skills we gained during the course and was also not reflective of the practice exams we had taken.
One strength is that it made me really think about the physical implications of the experiments. One weakness is that I felt there was a very tight time constraint of the midterm and final.
Every lab is very clearly structured.

One or two labs could have probably been substituted for experiments that were more relevant to course material (although it must be hard to design a curriculum meant to work together with multiple different courses). There were many opportunities to do well, though, and the questions posed in experiment background material was thought-provoking and helpful in understanding the material. The short post-lab writeup is also a strength of the course, and I appreciated that there was a midterm because it helped a lot in knowing what to expect in the final exam.
Good class! Not much to improve on

This was a really fair course and all the labs were reasonable and felt important. The midterm was also useful, however I thought the final was quite hard compared to what we were expected to do throughout the semester. The TAs were great as was Dr. Fleming.

The lab manuals are not up to date and sometimes I wonder when they will be updated. I feel this course is a bit difficult especially the final practical exam hence more practice exams should be provided.

The weekly labs are pretty good and straightforward and the lap reports are a good way to be sure you understood everything. In general, it's hard to prepare for the midterm and final exams and I wish there had been more ways to prepare.

It's not as time consuming outside of class, but we are not given much guidance or instruction. There's lots of help during classes, but there's not much clear written instruction. The course packet is not clear enough and doesn't give us clear directions on what to do.
Loved the practice midterm and finals!

For the midterm and the final, each multiple choice question was 10pts. On this midterm, this was 10% of the grade. This is really unfair because it meant that your letter grade could be changed just by missing one multiple choice question. 

I liked the lab report format (being a one page summary), but thought there could be more guidance on what was considered "guidance"
More time to explain the concepts.
I feel the class would be more meaningful if it was directly connected with the Physics 180 curriculum, but I understand this integration may not be possible for many students.

Strengths 
- Some of the labs helped me visualize physics concepts, particularly the one on inertia and momentum. 

Weaknesses 
- Overall the course has very little direct application or relation to PHYS 170.
- Most labs felt like a waste of time because they illustrated basic principles that were easy to grasp even without a laboratory demonstration.

This lab course is manageable (you turn in weekly one-page lab summaries to go along with a full in-lab write-up, rather than a lab report) for most of the semester. The labs are tedious and can ask rather challenging/confusing questions, but you can rely on your TA to get you through. The midterm and final exam, however, are so much harder than the labs you're used to doing, which seemed really unfair to me. For those assessments, you're on a strict time limit (one hour per experiment, as opposed to the three you usually spend on a regular lab day), and the questions you're asked can seem rather unreasonable in terms of difficulty. Not every question is like this, but one of the three experiments we had to do for the final exam was definitely excessive (one of the questions involved differential equations, which I'd never seen and was really confused by).

Grading seemed intensely subjective, and there were some students that felt almost targeted during grading- Despite not large changes in lab report content, there would be big disparities in grading. Overall, I really dont feel that I learned much about physics or scientific writing and that the material didnt match up with what I was learning in physics class, making this course a drag and probably the worst part of my week.
The class is organized to helped facilitate student learning. I felt I was learning physics principles while doing the labs. Enjoyed it!
The TAs are very helpful in class and the experiment notes were clearly made. The practice midterm was also very helpful.
Although the lab had a useful survey of many physics topics, the week-to-week grind held little excitement for me.
The study guide for the midterm and final exam was not effective. It's like a shot in the dark.

there are no "wild card" labs that are much harder than usual, and the work is pretty uniform thorughout the lab. 

The Exams are too short and highly stressful. they require a greater knowledge of formatting and working with a computer program than an understanding of the physics.

The strengths of this course were definitely the helpfulness of the teaching staff, the comprehensive nature of the background material for each lab and the ease of experimentation with the set procedures and protocol. A weakness in the lab would definitely be the final exam. I feel as though the final made the information we learned throughout the semester unnecessarily complicated and difficult to follow, thereby not truly testing the knowledge we gained.

Strengths: well organized, short summary instead of long lab reports, many professors to ask help

Weaknesses: uncertainty calculations, sometimes tedious labs

Good course. TAs are very helpful and knowledgable, and professional. Perhaps a bit more standardization between TAs in what kinds of mini pre-lab lectures are given, as well as what is expected for addendums would be helpful. Still, labs are often a bit too long. The same concepts could be covered in a shorter amount of time without students becoming disillusioned by the length of lab.

A strength of this course is that the labs contain enough material to provide one with an in depth understanding of the principle, without being so long that students get distracted and restless. On weakness might be the variability in the TAs, however mine was excellent and make sure that each student understood the purpose and material of each lab.
The lab manual was very clear and helped me get though the lab with minimal questions.

One strength of this course was the switch to the one-page lab reports. I saw what was expected in previous years (handwritten, many page long lab reports), and I was so grateful that we were allowed to type ours up. 
One weakness of this course was that it often felt like tedious, busy work. While I did think some of the lab days were interesting (gyroscope), other days (flipping a coin 100 times) felt really unnecessary, and I can't say I always came out of physics lab feeling like I learned something.

Strength: the lab instructions were often very detailed and explained things in a usually clear way although even then it was sometimes confusing and I couldn't see how it worked until I got to lab. Also strength: the 1-page lab write ups were good because other labs make you do pointless work that is very specifically formatted and there is seriously no need for a long pointless lab write up; a one-page summary does the job just fine. Weakness: this lab was just pointless. I really didn't learn anything and it was a waste of time. I only took it because it is a requirement for premed. Nobody was invested in it, everyone just wanted to get out of there. The experiments were tedious and dumb and usually demonstrated very very basic concepts so I didn't learn anything new.

In my opinion, there are many weaknesses of this course. First, I believe that the experiments in question should be more closely related to the topics taught in the introductory physics courses. Second, I believe that there should have been greater information provided about the midterm and final, in terms of how to prepare, when they were to take place, the format, etc. Third, I believe that there must be a better way to have midterm and final exams. To me, it does not make sense to have a midterm exam, in which you have to complete one experiment in an hour, and a final exam, in which you complete three experiments in three hours (one hour each), because during normal lab hours, you have three hours to complete one experiment in lab. In this way, I feel that the exams are more a test of quickness rather than a test of greater understanding and attention to detail.

Strength: Labs are pretty well laid out and structured for learning.
Weakness: Labs are very dependent on what your TA expects, so there is not much standardization across TA sections.

Based on previous course feedback, I believe that the instructors have worked on aligning the experiments more with the physics lecture courses (170 and 180) though this is not always possible and I do not think this should be expected in any way. It is designed to stand alone or as a loose companion. Most experiments are fairly straightforward and do have practical use in teaching skills for the laboratory. Grading is generally fair with 60% of your final course grade based on the weekly 4-question pre-lab quizzes and lab reports. With that being said, the midterm and the final practical exam are sound in theory but highly unsavory in reality. They are based on several concept areas covered in the labs from the semester but have been manipulated so that new information is presented as would be expected. The flaw lies with the time constraint that is significantly less for each exam problem despite the intended shorter length of the experiment. Each question is also incredibly dependent on the previous questions, which is always a poor way to structure exams. All in all, the exams were not fair and representative of the duration of the course and felt contrived to fill in the remainder of the grade. I would recommend greater emphasis on improving the labs and less on an attempt to generate a larger standard deviation in grades.

I think the course is largely structured very well. I liked having a page limit for the lab reports although sometimes it was hard to get all of the information down in our lab notebooks during the lab period itself.

It was a well-structured course. Love the style of lab reports and the set-up of the lab in general. However, would be nice if there was more communication between the lab and lecture course. Sometimes, there were concepts that we learned in lab before being introduced to it in lecture. Without having the conceptual background, it was difficult to understand what was happening in real-time.

Strengths: the course is well-organized and efficiently run, with clear expectations and feedback given with every lab report. Lab reports only take 1-2 hours, which is wonderful compared to other labs. It is nice to have a very transparent course.  

Weaknesses: Labs themselves can be tedious. Some feel like a waste of time (that penny flip experiment...). I have heard that TA quality/grading varies a lot (hopefully this is accounted for when doing final grades). The lab isn't very flexible in case you want to move lab days, which is frustrating since sometimes certain things come up. Final is SUPER STRESSFUL (extremely fast pacing).

The course is pretty straightforward but I think it could be more clear what is expected for the lab reports early on in the course. I think feedback could have been more prompt for the midterm and final.

This course simply needs to cut down on the uncertainty calculations. We can all do basic math. Testing it week after week shows nothing (and certainly nothing about our physics knowledge). It's simply a way to waste our time and keep us there.

Honestly, this was a really great little lab. Like with most TFs, mine took a little getting to know him, and if you wanted to keep all your points, you had to make sure to draw diagrams, write out procedures even if they were already there, and notate units. But really, it was quite chill and 3 hours is the perfect time slot. Maybe I would have liked a bit more in-depth view of some of the physical concepts, if I had to choose a weakness.
The course was very well organized and grading was consistent and feedback was good.
The grading of the lab handouts should somehow become more consistent and standardized so that there aren't great deviation in the average points awarded by each TA.
Glad they offered the midterm for 165 this year too - thanks!
Great course but at times, especially with the final, it felt like 180 kids had a great advantage over 170 from sheer familiarity with the material alone..

Better than chemistry lab but still a lab. The midterm/final lab differs greatly from the pace and skills set by the ususal lab work. They seem much harder and I don't think it's the best way to test info.

The course is easy to follow, systematically organized, and the expectations are clear. However, I found that the lab books were somewhat excessive in how much we had to write about our procedures. I also found that the focus on error calculations sometimes got repetitive, and yet I was still confused about how to mathematically solve for certain errors. This could be improved through a more intuitive explanation in lab about these errors. 
I also found it very helpful that we had a midterm to practice for our final exam.

This lab was a very doable lab, with clear instructions in each lab handout that allowed for the directions to be easily followed. As a first-year who had never done any prior lab work, I believe that this is course was very well laid out to allow me to understand proper lab procedure and basic concepts such as uncertainties.

A strength of this course are the instructors and my TF (Xinyi Chen) who try very hard to instill important laboratory techniques and knowledge of fundamental physics in students. A weakness of this course initially was the knit-pickiness of grading in my section, but this style of grading changed after the second lab report.

I believe there are two major weaknesses in this course: 1) TA discrepancy and 2) lack of preparation/information about exams. TAs in this class varied quite a bit when it came to grading and while I don't know how this is accounted for, I hope it is. The Midterm and Final exams were certainly interesting and used clever ways of applying material but I believe we could have been given more information to prepare for this.
A painless lab course for once.

This course was ok. The biggest strength is the individual TA. I think the biggest weakness in this course are the exams. 1) They are not representative of what you do in the course. They are significantly harder than all the labs you do and you are given a time limit. Considering we did one lab a week in 3 hours, it does not really make sense that the final was 3 labs in one hour. 2) They treat the exams like it is a game, which does not seem respectful to students and again is not representative of the course. In order to ask a question during the exam, you must "buy it" aka minus ten points off. 3) Considering the exam/parts of the exam are out of a 100, it seems kind of strange that there were always two multiple choice questions EACH worth 10 points and correct answers on these were necessary for the rest of the lab. Overall, I am extremely disappointed in the way these exams were conducted. They were not fair and my grade suffered because of it.
manuals were very clear, TAs were great, but lab reports were at times too much work for the 0.5 credit course
The course taught effectively but was tedious and I thought it focused too much on error.
Overall, this course is well organized and the expectations are clear. It's very straightforward and not a lot of work.
Paired well with lecture course (I took 180). Some theoretical concepts were sort of "breezed over" (such as drag) which hurt me on the exam.
I enjoyed most of the labs but the coin flipping one was definitely a little boring. Overall, I think the structure of the class is well set up.

The experiments were pretty straight forward, but sometimes there would be hard aspects of the experiments that we would quickly brush aside, which was sometimes confusing.
As a student in the 170 class, a lot of the topics discussed were part of the 180 lecture and not ours. That made some of the concepts more difficult to grasp.

It is a hard course, I would spend time reading the lab and doing my best but it didnt seem to be enough. They were interesting experiements, but we need more information and more examples so we can understand. There needs to be more resources available to those students who are struggling, since some students just seemed to understand while others were taking longer to understand.

It would be more interesting to have more applicable experiments. The labs did not often take up the full time but always required help from our TA. As a result, I did not feel that we were at all adequately prepared for the midterm or final, which you must complete under almost impossible time constraints with no help. I hated the format of these exams, which make what could be an enjoyable lab extremely stressful for no good reason. I felt that PHYS 170 kids were at a disadvantage, as the concepts brought up in the lab had been covered much more extensively in 180.

This course was highly organized, effective, and just all-around pretty cool. I learned a lot from the well-designed experiments and thorough manuals, but I appreciated that you gave students enough room to develop some of their own hypotheses and procedures. Having taken several other labs at Yale, I also appreciated that this course was truly a half-credit, and the staff made an effort to make the material interesting and challenging but not overwhelming or full of busy work. I really feel like I learned useful skills in this course, not just lessons in physics (though I did learn a good deal of those) but also general lab technique. The entire teaching staff was attentive and knowledgeable, and I felt like they really cared about my success and learning. Finally, I truly enjoyed the practical exams--they had the right balance of difficulty and whimsy! Even though I was not very excited about taking this class at the beginning of the semester, it ended up being my favorite course this term, and I think that change in mindset speaks to the high quality of the course material and staff.

Strengths: The weekly labs and lab reports are a good way of measuring the extent to which you worked through and internalized the material.

Weaknesses: The practicals were a load of garbage. They're just poorly written versions of the regular labs, and the test is to see if you can figure out what they're actually talking about. Labs are extremely boring, but competent.
The course can often be very tedious

I thought this course could be bettered if the exams were more representative of what we learned in lab. I felt like the exams were more difficult than what we had done in class and that they were on material we had not learned in lab, and sometimes on things I had not learned in lecture either.
Final was very hard and not indicative of midterm or labs AT ALL
This course is structured very well.
I enjoyed participating in some labs that challenged me to think ways I hadnt before. I did not like the labs that did not highlight new concepts and could have been better taught in a lecture.
overall i thought it was a good course

I think the course has a good formula. My only change would be to try and hand back lab reports before the following week's lab report is due. I sometimes found myself losing points on two labs in a row because I didn't have the chance to see my TA's comments on the previous week's report before having to submit the current week's report.
No one likes lab, but as they go physics isn't too bad. The labs are tedious but doable.
The grading scale needs to be adjusted. People with less physics background have a much more difficult time. Grading consistency seems to vary from TA to TA.

The final exam should not be weighted as heavily because it does not reflect the amount of time spent on the labs during the course of the semester. Also, labs focused on concepts that were not covered equally in PHYS 170 as compared to PHYS 180. This was an issue when preparing for the final exam. I felt that I was learning physics concepts when reading lab handouts which did not provide sufficient material to completely understand the concepts.
The course strengths were in the experiments themselves. One weakness was that there seemed to be no standard for grading the lab reports.
Great TFs and course coordinators, the class is also organized to match the physics lecture class very well.

The weekly experiments were pretty reasonable and it was not difficult to complete them in the class period.  The midterm and final exams were much harder by comparison, and we did not feel like we could prepare adequately for them.

The experiment outlines were always extremely helpful in learning the material, as I was not being taught this information in my physics class. However, the lab was very much tailored to match the normal physics class instead of the one focusing on the life sciences. Because of this, I often struggled to make many of the connections I needed to.
Honestly, don't take it if you don't have to. I found the labs a bit pointless and never felt like I was learning something.
You are probably taking this class because you have no choice. This is a horrible lab course. I wish you luck because you are going to need it.

This course was not bad except for the final, which seemed grossly unfair and not representative of what we had learned during the semester. If the final had been more consistent with what they had taught us during the semester, then this could be a great class.
yep! like me, you're probably required to take it. Even so, I would say that this course was perfectly fine (especially when taken with friends, and if your TA is fun).
DEFINITELY TAKE IT!!! This lab is very reasonable and a lot of fun.

The only people who take this course are those who have no choice, so my recommendation is irrelevant. However, if you are one of those people and are reading this review, don't worry! This course is pretty chill. It's many magnitudes better than gen chem lab in every regard, and it's one of the lowest workload courses I have ever taken. Some of the experiments and reports can be a bit dry and math heavy, but overall the content was pretty good and I enjoyed the course.

If you have to take physics lab then you are probably going to take this class anyways. This class is not that much work and only requires you to do a one page writeup each week for lab. Oftentimes labs don't take the full three hours so you can get out early a lot of times.
You're probably only taking this if you have to-- one of the more tolerable labs at yale.

Personally, I found it a little challenging sometimes (especially the final practical exam). It involved a lot of math, and was something that was difficult to prepare for. I studied a lot for IT and felt it did not really help me. This may just be as I didn't have a strong physics background prior to this semester.

I would recommend this course, although it is likely that those in this course need it for their major or pre-med requirements. I thought it was interesting enough, but was not overwhelmingly or needlessly tedious.
Only if required.
If you need a physics lab for medical school, etc., PHYS 165L is a good choice.
Yes, this lab was enjoyable and you learn a lot. Even though it's a 3 hr lab, it's not that bad. The lab reports are also limited to one page which is very nice.

Only take the lab if you need it. It's not particularly interesting or exciting, but it gets the job done. It feels a lot like high school physics lab in that you will do the same things like measure velocities and track collisions and such. Logger Pro can be a pain of a software to use. 

That being said, the course seems fair enough. The post labs are concise and not superfluous. The reason why I don't recommend it is because the exams are completely unrepresentative of the rest of the class. In the rest of the class, if you put in the time and pay attention, you can get a good grade and do well. 

The practical exams however are extremely stressful. Three experiments are stuffed into three hours into the final, and you are not allowed to ask questions. The pressure is so high, and it feels so unrepresentative of how lab work will be done in the future. No collaboration? Timed? I would have much preferred a written exam and a practical without the time pressure.
Wouldn't recommend unless you have to take it.
take it if you need phys lab, don't take it bc you want to. it's alright in terms of labs - less work than orgo or chem but more confusing imo
If you're taking this course, it's probably because you have to. The workload is extremely manageable, though, and the TF's are super nice and helpful!

The only issue with this Physics lab is that the exams (which are practicals) were significantly harder than any of the experiments performed throughout the semester. Although the midterm was doable, the final practical exam was noticeably difficult. Otherwise, it is fairly easy to do well in this class.
I would not recommend this class. But you almost certainly have to take it.
Don't take this course for fun.  It's designed to fulfill requirements and does not provide the student with anything they couldn't learn in a general physics course.
For those in the STEM fields yes
You will take this class because you are premed. I'm sorry.

Phys lab is overall a good class! The experiments are fairly well-designed and mostly pretty fun to do. The class can feel a bit disorganized at times - at first it's not clear what should be written in the post-lab reports - but the grading for the reports is fairly generous.

A basic physics lab course that asks you to apply concepts from class in a fairly straightforward manner. Weekly lab reports are only a page long, and the most challenging topic throughout the semester is probably error propagation.
You are taking this if its required with the physics class, it's a pretty decent lab and not much outside work.

Not a bad lab to take in all honesty, not too much work, but the final practical exam is a good challenge. Not difficult enough to make you hate the course, but enough to make you feel like your earning your grade. Can't complain.
Well, you gotta take it if you have to-- def not the worst lab (in fact, the best I've taken at Yale so far), so pair it with another required lab if you can/must

No. This course was horrible, and caused me so much anxiety and stress. Its poorly taught, the lab assignments are out of synch with lecture material (I took Phys 180 and it was rare that anything we learned in class correlated with lab), and the labs themselves are confusing and assume you know a lot about physics already. I often found myself having to apply concepts I did not understand to lab procedures that were not well written. At times, when I couldn't teach myself the material based off of the lab packets, I found myself just floundering through a three hour lab. Also, the grading feels somewhat arbitrary and it is very hard to get any feedback that isn't "you didnt include insight" (on that note, what even is insight? Truly feel like that was never explained). Not to mention, the practicals are really difficult and care more about your math ability than your ability to use the equipment in the lab. Even then, the math is really confusing and often felt inaccessible to me. I really tried in this class. I asked for extra help and did a ton of uncertainty practice on my own time, and I don't think any of it paid off. I often left lab feeling really dejected and super unconfident in my ability to do better the next time I had to go in.  A truly and utterly terrible class. Don't take if you don't have to.
If you're taking it, you have to take it. Would not recommend to anyone else.
Take this course if you need to. No one takes this course if they are not required for their major.
Why would you take lab besides for a requirement? It's a fine course though!
Do not take unless you have to.
Yes this is a great laboratory introduction course, there is plenty of support, and you cover a lot in a semester.
If you're taking it, you probably have to take it.

I would likely recommend this course or something higher level to someone with more physics experience. It is necessary for understanding the practicality of physics experiments. Many majors also need this course for the courseload.
I would recommend the class, but if you are taking PHYS 170 some of these concepts might be new to you so look them up ahead of lab.
I would not recommend this course. It is not worth the stress.
In one word: brutal.

I would only recommend this course to people who either really like physics or who need to take it. For students who aren't interested in physics, the lab requires a lot of time, thought, and calculation, and while the concepts can be interesting (such as the radioactivity lab), the labs themselves can be long and not engaging if you're not interested in the material.

Yes. Most people take this class as a prerequisite, and I think it works well as just that--it's easier than 205 but still teaches you about lab technique and good notebook keeping procedures. It was not very exciting but I expected that coming in with a strong physics background.

I mean if you're going to take it, you probably have to. Everything is fine, but the final is really hard, but I'm thinking positively! I really liked my TF and most people I know had similar experiences, so I think it's actually not a bad class, considering it's an intro physics lab and most people would be taking something else if they could.
Yes, I would say this is a good lab course that is definitely manageable.
It's kind of one of those things that you take because you need to.

You're probably taking this because you have to, either for your major or premed. It's a necessary evil, but it's not that bad. The lab reports are one page, typed, single spaced. They're pretty easy to write, but the grade you get will vary depending on which teaching fellow you have (some are harsh graders, some easy). If you read the lab handouts before class and have a basic understanding of what's going on you'll be fine. From my experience and what I've heard from my classmates, the practical exams (midterm, final) will either be okay or completely wreck you, there's no inbetween.
Yes, to learn about physical measurement.
Not a terribly hard class (except the final was a bit iffy...) and a easy lab compared to genchem lab.
I would recommend this course to another student.
I would recommend physics lab to reinforce the concepts from lecture without excessive work outside of lab time.
I would recommend this! It was fun, and I learned a lot of great things
You probably have to take this course, but as far as premed labs go I thought it was quite fair and well taught.
I would not recommend this class unless you absolutely have to take it.
If you have to take it, take it. If you don't, don't bother.
If you have to take it, take it, but be prepared to sit there for a lot of unnecessary hours doing work.
Take it for the .5 credit it is easy and little work.
This course is helpful in reviewing physics.
Yes very relaxed
Frankly, this course is a requirement.  There is nothing bad about it, and if someone needed a physics lab, I would have no problem recommending it.
Honestly, this lab may require less work than something like Orgo lab, but it was sooo much less interesting. Buckle up for a boring semester.

I'd recommend this course only if you actually need to take it for your major/pre-med requirements. If you're looking for a lab to fulfill science credits, orgo lab is the way to go. In terms of comparison, I'd say physics lab is slightly better than gen chem lab, but almost as tedious.
Do you really have a choice? I suspect not.
You probably have to take this course, and it's pretty fair in terms of how lab courses go. I think it's more straightforward than other lab courses, so I would recommend taking it.
Only take this lab if you have to.
Only if they are pre-med, because why?
No, it was incredibly boring

No. The labs are fine, but the exams are stressful and success in them requires more knowledge of working with LoggerPro than knowledge of physics. 

The course instructors are very rude.
I would recommend this course to another student because the topics are fairly interesting and the workload is doable, but the lab could be made to incorporate more independent thought.
It seems that many students taking this course are doing so because they have to. It's not horrible, but if you don't particularly love the subject matter, it's not fun.
I would recommend this course as it did not include a large workload, but was helpful in my understanding of physics.
This lab matched up nicely with the intro physics classes.

While I would say that I wouldn't recommend this class, this is (I think) the only intro lab class that counts for most majors/pre-med requirements so there isn't a lot of choice to begin with. I've also heard that 205L is much, much worse.

No. Don't take it unless you absolutely have to. Otherwise it will be a waste of your time. Also, WHY ARE LABS NOT A FULL CREDIT?? I easily spend as much time on this class as on my once a week seminars.
No, I would not recommend this course to another student. The only reason I took this class was for pre-med requirements and I would not recommend it unless you needed to take it.
Yeah, pretty good lab. Only 3 hours long. Short write-ups. Pretty chill overall. You probably have to take it for requirements anyways though....
No, it is the worst class i've taken at Yale but a lot of people will have to take it anyway.

Based on previous course feedback, I believe that the instructors have worked on aligning the experiments more with the physics lecture courses (170 and 180) though this is not always possible and I do not think this should be expected in any way. It is designed to stand alone or as a loose companion. Most experiments are fairly straightforward and do have practical use in teaching skills for the laboratory. Grading is generally fair with 60% of your final course grade based on the weekly 4-question pre-lab quizzes and lab reports. With that being said, the midterm and the final practical exam are sound in theory but highly unsavory in reality. They are based on several concept areas covered in the labs from the semester but have been manipulated so that new information is presented as would be expected. The flaw lies with the time constraint that is significantly less for each exam problem despite the intended shorter length of the experiment. Each question is also incredibly dependent on the previous questions, which is always a poor way to structure exams. All in all, the exams were not fair and representative of the duration of the course and felt contrived to fill in the remainder of the grade. I would recommend greater emphasis on improving the labs and less on an attempt to generate a larger standard deviation in grades.
I would 100% recommend this sequence. The pre-labs were helpful and labs organized logically. And the lab reports are only a page long!

Straightforward lab with clear expectations and feedback given with every lab report (which only takes 1-2 hours to write each week). Workload and material is mostly painless, though labs themselves can be tedious/boring (but never difficult). BEWARE THE MIDTERM/FINAL - they are tricky and you don't get enough time.
Take it if you have to, it's not that bad. Grading is somewhat arbitrary and just make sure you figure out what is expected on the lab reports early on.
its fine, especially if you get a nice tf
no
Please don't take it if you don't have to.
Yes, it's a very good way to get your required lab credit (nobody would take it for fun). If you're choosing between gen chem lab and this, it's this all the way.
Reasonable amount of work, still learn a decent amount, would recommend.
I would recommend this course because it's very little work for half a credit. Definitely worth the three hours a week in the lab and hour and a half I spent preparing for lab.
I would recommend this course to another student because it covers material relevant to the lecture classes.
Only if it is a prerequisite for their major.
Yeah it's perfectly fine!
Only take it if you need it
No, but you must if you are looking at this.
This lab is not the most engaging, but it is also not that difficult. Take it if you need to.

Really easy lab course, often finish an hour early, the lab writeups are super easy and short (can do in 20 min before class)
Lab final was crazy hard though (probably was curved)
Yes, I would strongly recommend this course to a student taking PHYS 180 or even PHYS 200, because it is a relaxed lab setting that allows students to be introduced to proper lab procedure.

Take this lab if you have to, as weekly reports (even though they are 1-page assignments) take a lot of time because you often cannot finish writing the answers to questions in the handout during lab. I can't say I enjoyed staying up late at night doing the reports, but I did enjoy the experiments themselves, as well as the opportunity to work with a new lab partner each week.
You have to take it, but it really is painless. The instructors do everything they can to make sure it is understandable, even if you don't get physics af all.

If you are pre-med, I am sorry you have to take this course. If you don't have to, then I would take another course. Everyone says physics lab is better than the other lab courses (and for a while it was), but the exams were wayyyy harder than all the other premed labs.
This lab was okay, not too bad!
This lab is not difficult but it can be tedious. Make sure you know LoggerPro really well for the practicals.
Yes!
Yes, it's a relaxed lab course but you still learn some stuff and it does reinforce some concepts you learn about in 180.

I personally don't find physics labs very exciting, but it was a well designed course. The lab reports weren't too hard (just one page a week), but the final was really challenging so do prepare for that. This year they were not flexible about doing makeup labs, which was annoying.
The staff of 165L tries to make it an enjoyable experience and it's honestly pretty good. The labs are a little tedious, but you do get to see the things you learn in lecture in real life.
Yes, hands-on labs are important to learning physics concepts
Yes, I would recommend this class to another student, since it is a great class to take along the intro physics lecture course.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It is taught well.
No, its a hard course, unless you have a strong background. Only take if you have to.

Would not recommend this lab unless you absolutely have to take it, but you probably do anyways. The midterm and final, which I think were new this year, make this course so stressful and they are graded harshly.

This course is the best lab I've taken at Yale. The experiments are very well designed, the teaching staff is highly engaged and knowledgeable, and the work is entirely manageable and reasonable for a half-credit. I would highly recommend this course.
You are probably taking this because you have to. It is not painful other than the mind-numbingly stupid practicals.
Yes, I think it was a great way to gain a better understanding of physics concepts and learn how to use lab equipment.
Take this lab! It is a good way to fulfill requirements. You better understand the content presented in class and it's not too much work.
Wouldn't take unless you have to for your major. It's not much work, just tedious.
I would not recommend this class to another student unless it is necessary for their major/ for pre med.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The physical principles learned are applicable to a variety of fields.
Take this course if you have to.
I would not go out of my way to badmouth this class, but I do not think it was very well organized.
not unless required

Standard physics lab. You'll probably get the most out of it if you're an engineer and deal with uncertainties and error measurements frequently. It's not very useful for pre-meds or people in other STEM fields. The good news is it's not very hard, especially if you have some physics background (if you've taken high school physics and are concurrently enrolled in intro physics you'll breeze through it). Lab reports require a bit more time and effort than the 1 page limit would suggest, but it's not too arduous. Writing them is much more pleasant if you take good quality notes while doing the experiment rather than having to rewrite them later.
You probably have to take it, so take it. If you're just looking for a good half credit or SC credit, it's not a terrible option.
Only take this course if you are genuinely interested in Physics or need to take it because of pre-med / major requirements.

I would recommend this to anyone who is required to take the course. The labs are easy to follow, but they are misleading when preparing for the final exam. Students taking PHYS 170 may have more difficulty understanding the concepts than students in PHYS 180.
I would recommend to those who require it.
Yes this is great lab class to accompany any physics class.
It's fine. Useful and not incredibly difficult but you do will need to put the work in

This course is probably a prerequisite that you would have to take, but regardless it is not too bad.  There is not much work involved outside of class besides the one-page reports, and the labs themselves are boring for the most part, but not too difficult.  The TAs are very helpful if you have trouble getting through the lab.

I would definitely recommend this course to someone taking the main physics course, as I believe it is well organized and structured. However, it never covers any material taught in the life-sciences physics class, so there is a major disconnect there.
